awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Dual enzyme system to prevent food waste caused by oxygen
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is development of new technology for safe, recyclable, and effective packaging.  The system works by protecting packaged contents from damage from oxygen (technically termed oxidation).  An estimated 25% of the world’s food supply is lost due to food spoilage, with oxidation a major contributor to the problem. Technology that contributes to food security is a compelling objective in the 21st century. Today’s methods of protection from oxygen require metals or complex and expensive barrier materials. These options inhibit efficient recycling. Reduction in packaging waste is an increasing goal.  Industries agree that current products for oxygen protection are not meeting needs or consumer preferences. This proposal describes a solution based on a pair of enzymes that use minute quantities of sugar to consume oxygen by producing a modified sugar and water.  Enzymes perform a specific function (catalyze a chemical reaction) and are inherently environmentally friendly.  For many foods, the sugar in the food itself powers the system.   

The proposed project seeks to determine the viability of a dual enzyme, oxygen removal system for preservation of food quality in real world packaging applications.  Prototype materials have demonstrated sufficient performance to justify this research, and a series of technical objectives have been defined.  Objectives include determining the oxygen removal activity in a variety of containers and designing optimal product configurations in different containers.  A second objective is to determine system performance at various temperatures.  Active shelf-life of the system – activity over time – needs to be evaluated.  Defining these criteria is required in order to determine the commercial potential of the technology.  Enzyme activity assays are key tasks for all objectives.  Oxygen removal effectiveness will be determined by an industry standard for measuring oxygen incursion into sealed packages.  The proprietary cell lines developed for expression of the enzymes in the system have been screened for production potential at commercial scale.  All required enzymes will be produced in house under previously developed standard operating procedures for fermentation and purification. Interfacing with developers of new, environmentally benign packaging materials is ongoing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview:  Oxygen is a key instigator of decomposition and food spoilage.  It is oxygen that turns beer “skunky”, causes discoloration of fruits and vegetables, and powers changes in flavor profiles of coffee and wine.  None of the oxygen barrier or oxygen reduction products on the market today fully satisfy the needs of the packaging industry.  Additionally, many of today’s solutions impede recycling of packaging materials.  NECi has developed an enzyme-based system for removal of oxygen from air or liquids in closed containers.  NECi’s dual enzyme oxygen removal system is powered by tiny amounts of sugar, leaving behind a modified sugar and water. NECi’s technology removes oxygen to parts per million.  Competing product literature shows performance in per cent – parts per hundred.

The consumer packaged goods (CPG) sector needs to know that the dual enzyme system works effectively to remove oxygen from a closed container over a range of temperatures. In Phase I, we determined that the dual enzyme system is robust over time at various temperatures.  We developed a small, one square inch packet or sachet enclosed in off-the-shelf plastic film (GladWrap®) works well to remove oxygen from air or from liquid in bottles made of common plastics, PET and PE. The quantity of enzymes required is low and reasonable enough to encourage proceeding with commercialization.  


Intellectual Merit:  Phase I has demonstrated that NECi’s dual enzyme system can be used as an effective oxygen scavenger in food and beverage packaging.  The dual enzyme system was developed during NECi’s biosensor R&D, where the oxygen signal swamped that of the analyte (nitrate) being detected; US patent 9,187,779 was granted in 2015 for sensor applications.  The proposal highlights the potential of this enzyme driven method to replace the non-recyclable and not fully effective oxygen scavengers in use today. Previous attempts to utilize enzymes to scavenge oxygen in packaging generated unfavorable by-products plus a change in pH. The approach outlined in this proposal uses a unique enzyme pair.  This is the key innovation to enabling a green biotech solution to the problem of oxygen permeation for packaging.


The system continues to remove oxygen until the enzymes degrade into their component amino acids.  The quantity of enzymes required is very small, a few nanograms. All materials used in development of prototype packets, which we have named Oxybots™, are approved as safe for contact with food by the FDA.  No reaction products exit the Oxybots™.  NECi has developed proprietary, high-expressing cell lines for production by fermentation of both recombinant enzymes.  A US patent application has been filed for packaging applications of the system.


Broader Impacts:  The ultimate aim of this work is to participate in development of truly recyclable or biodegradable packaging with oxygen elimination capabilities.  Oxygen is a major driver of food spoilage and waste.  Competing oxygen barrier or removal technologies inhibit recycling, decomposition, or reuse of the base materials. The quantity of plastic packaging that has accumulated in oceans and landfill alarms everyone. Consumers, governmental agencies, and industry are driving the search for new materials to address the problem. The dual enzyme technology could be integral to the implementation of new circular economy products for the packaging industry.  NECi has recruited a team of industry insiders to guide this technology along practical pathways.

 


Last Modified: 09/19/2024
Modified by: Ellen R Campbell
